If a player correctly answers the question, he/she places a token on the number and colour that was answered. If not, play passes to the next person. A roll of a 6 is a "free will" where a player may select whichever space wanted.

The player wins with 5 tokens in a row, vertically or horizontally.

name: Wit / Farkel Double Game Pack
description:
Wit is a simple card game where players start with nine cards in their hand.

The object is to be the first player in a round to use all of the cards in your hand by forming words of 2 or more letters and eventually win the game by scoring 25 points. Players score points on the number of letters in a word - the more letters, the higher the score.

Players are also allowed to anagram other players words by adding one or more letters to the word to score points.

name: REACT-OR
description:
This game was developed on the heels of the Three Mile Island nuclear disaster in Pennsylvania.

The object of the game is to be the player with the least amount of radiation (identified in millirems or "Mr") when the nuclear reactor is brought to a cold shutdown.

The players, in some ways, represent water being cycled through the "cooling loops" of the nuclear power plant in an effort to reduce their radioactivity.

Each player starts out with 180 Mr of radiation identified by Mr cards in 10, 20, 50 and 100 Mr values. Card hands are kept secret - an important feature of the game. Radiation is reduced by 100 Mr with each completed circuit of the Cooling Tower loop, the longest of the three loops. While traveling through the loops, the player lands on Operation spaces and Mr spaces. The Operational spaces allow players to draw operation cards which might help to reduce their millirems, cause them to lose a turn, or increase/decrease the temp in the reactor core. Mr spaces add radiation to the player's hand.

Player's may also draw operation valve cards or other cards that might help them to effect a cold shutdown on the reactor. Valve cards prevent other players from moving around the loop. The challenge is in knowing when to shut down the reactor based on what you know about the other players' hands. Of course, the possibility also exists that the core temperature will rise to a meltdown point, which will also end the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Androids and Belt Bums
description:
This game is heavily based on Monopoly (as evidenced by the cover, which says "The Monopoly Stargame That Strikes Back!").

Players move around a not-entirely-linear board buying orbital stations and the like and charging rent (sorry, docking fees). There are some additional ways to make money such as mines and special side tracks on the board. Additional mechanics are mostly combat-related - players start with fighters and may buy frigates and battlecruisers. Players may fight each other or the fleets of the Empire, which is a neutral party that moves around the board taxing players (although players may take their fleets over sometimes, apparently - the rules are very hard to follow).

The box says it can be played by up to 12 people, but only 4 pawns are provided (and fighters come in just 3 colors - but organization does not seem to be the publisher's strong point). The components could fairly be described as primitive, except for the board, which is a bit garish but serviceable.

name: TriviGo
description:
TriviGo is The audio quiz game for people on the move.

Consists of an audio CD featuring six separate quiz games, each of which lasts for about twelve minutes.

After each question, there is a pause for a few seconds before the answer is stated. Play in real time, or use your pause button to buy more time. Questions contain clues or memory aids in the form of humor and wordplay.

The game is designed to facilitate repeated play and trivia practice-questions are medium to hard in difficulty.

Questions feature a variety of subject areas, with the majority related to modern and contemporary culture (literature to TV.)
categories: Educational, Electronic, Memory, Party Game, Real-time, Trivia, Word Game

name: Dragon Quest: Death Palace
description:
One of many boardgames loosely based off Enix's Dragon Quest RPG videogame series (known as Dragon Warrior in the US).

This one plays most like The Warlock of Firetop Mountain or TSR's Dungeon!. Go into the various rooms, take a random event card, battle monsters, get treasures, and try to get the medallions that will grant access to the Treasure Room.

name: Super Xevious
description:
Boardgame based off the arcade shooter of the same name.

Flying your ship about the levels (rolling the dice to move). Battle enemies on the ground by rolling dice, battle ones in the air via card combat. Build up your shields and power up your blaster as you progress through the levels. Each 'level' is a different board, and there's 7 levels (boards) in all. Cute little spaceships for your pieces.

name: Ghosts N' Goblins
description: Board game based off the arcade classic, you play a knight trying to defeat the demon Loki. Roll the dice to move along the board, battle monsters as you proceed, and fulfill requirements to go from one section to the next.

name: Godzilla Electronic Wargame
description:
Hex based Japanese wargame starring Godzilla and various other Toho monsters.

Includes scenarios for both one player (Godzilla vs. the earth defense force) and 2 players; earth creature(s) vs. space creature(s). Includes a "MyCom" electronic device with 6 LED lights for helping resolve combat, counters, a two-sized map, and 5 cute little miniatures for the monsters.
categories: Electronic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Heavy Metal L-Gaim (MyCom)
description:
Japanese game based off an anime show.

Plays somewhat like a simpler BattleTech. Includes a "MyCom" electronic device with 6 LED lights to resolve combats. Uses both counters and includes 8 plastic robots for the main mechs in the series. Has both space and land missions.
categories: Electronic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Flowers and Tears and Payday
description:
Parker Brothers attempt to make a game that would appeal to a Japanese crowd. It is similar to the game Pay Day in that it uses a calendar as its board, but it is not just a Japanese language version of it.

Players are Japanese businessmen (salaryman) trying to juggle the worries of a job, the bills, and a wife.

name: Transformers Scramble City
description:
Based off the original toy line of the Transformers Universe.

This is mostly a roll-and-move game with gimmicks such as a little ball that shoots out from the center area that you hope doesn't hit your robots. It used a partially 3d board and was aimed at a younger crowd.

name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #4: The Battle of Britain
description:
4th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series takes place in World War 2, with Britain fighting the Germans in the skies.

Do not confuse with Battle of Britain.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Electronic, Wargame, World War II

name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #5: The Battle of Kawanakajima
description:
5th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around a battle in medieval Japan that took place in 1561.

name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #7: The Siege of Osaka in the Summer
description:
7th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around the Siege of Osaka in 1615 (in the summer!). The Summer Battle was actually a field battle-the siege of the Castle had taken place over the Winter of 1614-15. The official English title on the box is "The Sierge of Osaka in the Summer", but "Sierge" is a typo/mistranslation on their part.

name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #8: Battle of the Midway
description:
8th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around airplane combat in the Pacific Ocean between America and Japan during World War 2.

name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #9: Battle of Nagashino
description:
9th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series takes place in 1575 Japan. One interesting aspect of the battle simulated was that there was a traitor who switched sides early in the fight. In the game, if his side takes 3 of more casaulties in turn 1, he switches sides immediately. If not, he remains loyal throughout the game.

name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #10: Battle of Pearl Harbor
description:
10th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers around the bombing of Pearl Harbor in World War 2.

name: Epoch Wargame Electronics #11: Battle of Dannoura
description:
11th of 12 games in the Epoch Wargame Electronics series. Each of the games features easy to learn rules (in Japanese), quick games that average about 30 minutes (not including setup), magnetic pieces on a set board, and an electronic dice-roller with 6 LED dots to work out the effects of combat.

As long as one player knows the rules, the other player does not need to know any Japanese in order to play the game.

This particular entry in the series centers a battle in Japan, in the year 1185.

name: L-Gaim Mark II
description:
Alternate but not official title: "Heavy Metal L-Gaim Mark II"

Complexity level 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Based off the mecha anime Heavy Metal L-Gaim, this takes L-Gaim to space, with 6 single-sided space maps and 300 new counters. This is a seperate and complete game from the original, ownership of the original is not required. However, both games use the same expansion kit.

Expanded by:

Heavy Metal L-Gaim Expansion kit
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: L-Gaim Mark II: Sveet
description:
Complexity level 2 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Based off the mecha anime Heavy Metal L-Gaim, this is a space-based 2 player hex & counter wargame.

Extremely tough to find in Japan, this is not an expansion to any of the other L-Gaim games, but an alternate, easier to learn (but of course still in Japanese) wargame.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Wheaties Sports Trivia Game
description:
A sports trivia game that celebrates 75 years of General Mills' Wheaties cereal.

From the box:

The object of the game is to score as many points as possible in Divisional, Conference, and Playoff rounds to get to the Winners Circle. Once in the Winners Circle, players vie for the Championship Ring. Points are scored by correctly answering trivia questions on tennis, golf, football, hockey, auto racing, baseball, the Olympics, basketball, and a special "All Champions" sports section that touches on nearly every champion and sport known to man. Along the way you try to obtain strategic advantage by landing on Playbook spaces. If you are lucky you get some draft picks, pick-up season-making free agents, figure out a team game plan, or make trades for the stretch run.

name: Armored Trooper Votoms: Battling
description:
Complexity level 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Based off the science fiction mecha anime Armored Trooper Votoms.

Says "The Role Playing game of Battle in the Votoms", but it's really more along the lines of Battletech than what most call a Role-Playing Game.

For a change of scenery from most of Tsukuda's 'outdoor' wargames, this takes place in an Arena.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Kabushiki Nyuumon
description:
Approximate English Translation: Introduction to Stocks

Part of Bandai's Game for Adult - "IF" series.

Game for Adults meaning aimed at older players, not anything with objectionable content.

"If" just refers to the their gimmick of setting up each game in the series as a "What if... (insert game scenario)"

Complexity 1 on Bandai's 1-7 scale (1=easiest)

This is a roll-and-move type board game, with the spaces you land on affecting the value of stocks in the game. You have limited control over your movement, and want to try going to the areas that will help your stocks more and devalue your opponents stocks.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Spiral Zone
description:
One of Bandai's Party Joy series of games (#83), a light series of games released only in Japan.

This one has cute little guys in powered armor battling each other. The game uses counters on a modular hex map. The hexes are plastic, each with their terrain shown on them, and they interlock, so you can arrange the board however you like.

name: Kamen Rider Club: Matrix Taisen Game
description:
Number 8 in the Matrix Taisen game series.

According to the information for this one, there are at least 8 games in the series. Each comes with many 3x3 grid board sections that can be rotated and placed in any configuration. Also, games may be combined, but games 1-4 are one set that is incompatible with games 5-8. Each features SD ('Super Deformed') character, cute-ified versions of regular characters.

In this game, the combatants are from the Kamen Rider TV show.

name: Gradius
description:
Part of Bandai's Party Joy series of lighter boardgames (#60), and one of the more collectible ones (as in expensive nowadays) in the series.

This is based off the 80s arcade space shooter of the same name. The board is split into 8 sections, each with its own rules. The things that remain the same are that each uses a square-grid for movement, and you can power up your ship by getting the capsules.

name: Fortune Quest
description:
Based off the anime/manga Fortune Quest, this game plays very similar to Talisman. You traverse the outer board fighting weaker monsters, getting gold, experience, and items. When all the lesser monsters are defeated, then you can attempt to defeat the "boss monster" (which can be one of a few different characters).

The player that defeats the boss monster wins.

name: Macross: Love is Passing Away
description:
Part of Bandai's Party Joy line (#48), a lighter series of boardgames. This one is based off the science fiction anime action/drama Macross. The game has you moving through a Zentraedi spaceship. You can switch between Fighter, Gerwalk, and Battroid forms for different movement and combat capabilities.

Besides the rulebook, there is also Japanese text on the event cards in the game.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Monster Maker: Demon Slayer
description:
Based off the "Monster Maker" series of card games. In this game you move along an overland map, uncovering events/monsters in each area, and go on monster hunts to defeat monsters.

The game is still card-heavy in gameplay. You're attempting to strengthen yourself so that you can defeat the demon. Each card can be read normally and turned upside down (not flipped over). You read it one way when you are drawing it as a monster card, and the other way around when its a treasure/companion/event.

name: Monster Maker: Dungeon Wars 2
description:
Based off the Monster Maker card game, this is a all-out dungeon crawl. It has two completely different games. The first is a solitaire dungeon crawl. There are 3 decks of cards. The first basically details the rooms, with each card having lots of information on it to randomize what is in the rooms, how much treasure is found, what kind of monsters you meet, what kind of traps you set off, and so on. There are also a deck of monster cards and treasure cards.

It looks as if the game was intended as a solitaire game, as the multiplayer game is more of a dungeon maze race, without all the combat, traps, or such. To illustrate, the multiplayer game is called the 'basic game' and only takes up 3 pages of the rulebook. The "RPG-type solo play' game takes up 11 pages of the rulebook.

name: Phaestos Disk
description:
Phaestos Disk is a real game from ancient Crete. The time frame is unknown, but it was before Minoan civilization according to archaeologists.

The board is made up of the "Phaestos Disk" ancient boards - which are two different boards, one on each side of the disk. There are 2-6 players. Each player has seven pawns. Each pawn has the signs of Minos era. There are also three dice with the ancient Hellenic shape.

All pawns must enter the first board, complete it and then go to the second board, do the same and then return back to the beginning. The first player who manages to exit all his pawns from the two boards is the winner. Each square has its own sign, each sign has a command to do (f.e. go 10 spaces, back 5 spaces etc), there are some positions in which the pawns have some penalties and some other which give more rolls or movements.

Phaestos Disk has the following items:
1. Two Color Boards (Disk of Phaestos, item from the Museum).
2. Seven pawns different color and shape for each of the four player.
3. Three dices with different shapes.
Of course there is a 32-page leaflet with some informations for this game with many photos from the ancient Crete Greece, the island of Deus.

name: Labyrinth of Minotaur
description:
Labyrinth of Minotaur [Minotauros] is an ancient board game.

This is a real ancient game from ancient Crete with boards found dating to about 1.000 B.C.

There are many boards, with Labyrinths on them.

There are 2-4 players. Each player has seven pawns. Pawns must have the signs of Minos era.

Also there are three dice with ancient Greek shapes on them.

The player with the highest die roll plays first. All pawns must enter the board make a run and then return to the beginning. The players chose the board.
Boards can be on a big board on both sides. Player who manages to exit all his pawns is the winner. Each square has its own sign; each sign has a command to do (i.e. go 10 spaces, back 5 spaces etc).
So the board game has the following items:
1. Some Colored Boards with Labyrinths.
2. Seven pawns different in color and shape for each of the four players.
3. Three dice with different shapes each one.
4. Many other items.
Of course there is a 32-page leaflet with some information for this game with many photos from ancient Crete and from Greece. (The island of Deus)
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move

name: High School of Blitz
description: An unusual collectible card game that centers on cute characters as its selling point. Each player plays someone who has become class president of a girl’s high school classroom, and tries to raise a group to save the world from destruction (and battle against the other classes).

name: Monster Maker Resurrection: The Monster Maker TCG
description:
Fantasy game with the Monster Maker characters. Vaguely similar to Magic, but only in the broadest sense.

Unlike the rest of the Mosnter Maker card games, this one is a collectible card game where players construct their own decks, instead of a fixed-deck set. Also, while the original artist does have cards he drew in this set, it is the first Monster Maker card game to use art from a variety or artists.

There are expansion sets produced for this game.

name: Hourai Card Game: Ganbare Athletics Meet
description:
A card game based off a high school athletics competition.

Cards with different values to the winner are used to represent different competitions, and you also have characters with different levels of athletic ability to use to try to win them. You can't reuse your athletes, so you'd like to use your best athlete for a high value competition, but then again, your opponents would want to do the same, and you may use your best athlete in hand for nothing because someone else has an even better one; whereas you could have used a lousy athlete in that case and while still would lose that competition, still have a very good athlete to use later.

name: Alien High School
description: Alien Highschool is a Japanese card game in which aliens have been infiltrating the Earth for more than 10 years. Their target is a super-weapon that lies beneath a metropolitan high school for girls. When the students learned of their plans, they band together to fend off the secret invasion. Players assume the roles of these students and use their cards to foil the alien schemes. When all incidents have been resolved, the player who foiled the most schemes is the winner. One of the player, however, could be an alien in disguise and might betray the team at any time.

name: Monster Hunt
description:
A fantasy game with unique monsters as opposed to having each combat simply being a different strength rating die roll. Monsters each have their own set of attacks: A Cockatrice has "Stone x2" and "Claw x2" for its attack, and is immune to holy spells and vulnerable to fire; A Ghoul has "Fang x1" and "Poison x2" attacks, and is immune to stone, song, poison, and curse based attacks.

This game is monsters vs. monsters, neither player has characters that act as adventurers/heroes. There is the usual variety of spells and items and events to affect the outcomes of combat between the monsters.

name: Lemlican Series 2: Lemlican Monsters
description:
2nd of an ambitious 3-part attempt to make an RPG card game. This set provides the monsters for the game.

Also playable as a stand-alone game, but really meant to be used with the others in the 3-part set.

Expands

Lemlican Series 1: Lemlican Musketeers Card RPG
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Seriously Silly
description: It will have you rolling on the floor with laughter... If you can even get the words out. Play this Seriously Silly game to learn from others what an "inflatable chicken" is and what a "mentholated hairline" is for. The trick is getting your opponent to believe you. So what are "freeze-dried underwear" for and what kind of person owns "turbo sheep"?
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Humor, Negotiation, Party Game, Word Game
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Betting and Bluffing, Cooperative Game, Role Playing, Storytelling

name: Monster Maker: The Queen of Darkness
description:
An amateur but near-professional quality unlicensed expansion for Monster Maker. Has additional cards, treasures, and events for Monster Maker. Requires the original Monster Maker game.

Expands:

Monster Maker
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Europe 1520
description:
If you like "Risk" and "Axis & Alies", you'll love this game. It's all the fun with half the learning. The year is 1520, a time of political and military upheaval as great empires juggled for world power. Meet face to face with great empires such as Ottoman, Iberian, Spanish, Mughal, Safid, Russian, Quing, Japanese, French, English, and more. Will you be the next great world leader? Play this classic strategy game and find out?

For details see http://ajaster.com/biglittlegames/europe1520.html
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: Be Forever Yamato Game
description:
Alternate name: Star Blazers Be forever Game

Based off the Space Battleship Yamato anime (known as Star blazers in the U.S.), the game comes in a very oversized box. It has a large board with a lot of different sections on it, with different gameplay on different parts of the board to simulate the epic story of the show.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Cat's Eye: The Last Big Game
description:
Based off the "Cat's Eye" anime show from the early 80s, about a trio of women thieves that wear leotard outfits and steal treasures.

Oversize game, with a very big multi-part board, along with many components (event cards, chips, information cards, roulette, playing pieces, and such).

name: Pack die Sieben
description:
Promotional family game, published by Mercedes Benz & Ravensburger.

Theme
A road trip with grandma, grandpa, mum, dad and three children, who all have to be put into the car so that you can be the first to reach the holiday destination.

Goal
Be the first to reach the finish line by successfully completing activities and being lucky in a roll-and-move part.

Game play
The game is divided into two phases:

In phase 1, players try to fill their car (= their player board) as fast as possible. They do so by completing tasks from the activity cards.
The first area of the board shows a track consisting of spaces in six different colours. There is one pawn for all the players. Players take turns rolling the die and move the pawn accordingly. Depending on the colour of the space the pawn lands on, the active player has to

mime or draw one of two words from the card and the other players guess what it is,
read a story from the card and everyone guesses if it is true or false,
guess if the other players will raise an even or an odd number of fingers,
write down what they associate with a word, and the other players have to guess.


Players who successfully complete a task and players who guess correctly get to spin a spinner showing the different family members. If they haven't already got this family member, they take a matching chip and put it on their player board. Otherwise they have to gift it to someone else.

If the pawn lands on a light or dark pink space, players play "The magical 7" (trying to come as close as possible to 7 with two die rolls - the winner spins the spinner) or "Spinner poker" (betting one of your chips to get to spin the spinner twice - if the spinner points towards the family member you were betting on, you win that chip, otherwise you lose the one you bet).

Phase 2: Once a player has filled his/her car, he/she proceeds to the second part of the board. Here, each player has a car pawn. Players try to reach the finish line as fast as possible. Obstacle tokens and event spaces make you lose or win family members. If a player lands on a space that is already occupied, he/she can steal a family member to fill an empty spot in their own car.

The first player to reach the finish line wins the game.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Recycling
description: The object of the game is to be the first player to get rid of all of their waste without going broke. The theme is about recycling products, and appropriately, the game components are all recycled materials: milk caps for movers, various beads and plastic chips for the waste products, etc.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Merge War
description:
Publisher's Description:

Acquire. Liquidate. Control.
Join the ranks of the global financial elite in Merge War. Take control of an international corporation, acquire the building blocks of world monopolies, and mercilessly steal assets to thwart your rivals! The first CEO to hit one trillion dollars wins, and has the world economy in his iron grip. In this game for 2-4 players, do you have what it takes to reach the top?

Contents:
46 game cards
2 reference cards
2 rules cards
All cards are black and white, business card size, and packaged in a small zip lock bag.

name: Living Life
description: Subtitled "the reality game that gets real," Living Life is more of an experience than a game. It comes with 30 real-life adventures designed to "guide you to live your life to the fullest." Examples of the cards: Watch the sun rise, contact old friends, and take a day trip.

name: Melvin the Moon Man
description: Space Explorers must roll the die and collect moonbucks along the way. The astronaut with the most moonbucks at the end of the game wins.

name: Fields of Chivalry
description: Fields of Chivalry is two games. "The Tourney" and "The Joust". The game is played on a fold out paper "board" with figures and scenery cut from card stock. Combat cards and a chart are used to determine outcomes.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Variable Player Powers

name: Audit: The Tax Game
description: This board game centers around the yearly encounter with the Internal Revenue Service and the preparations necessary to successfully deal with this confrontation. Players try to convert taxable money to non-taxable by landing on positions which contain various tax shelters and credits.

name: Cyber-Sea
description:
From the www.GamingReport.com review:

"Cyber-Sea by Delmer Esau is a new version of an independent board game for two to four players. Like the original game, The Fish Tank, each player of this game controls a team of soldiers including a ronin, a hacker, and three foot soldiers on a mission to rescue a genetic super fish. Well, rescue may be a little overly noble. Steal the genetic super-fish is a more accurate description of the game mission. Naturally, in the world of undersea warfare, the competition is fierce so killing as many of the enemy is a possibly close second game objective. The teams fight each other, while having to overcome locked hatchways, flooded chambers, and automatic guns. The game is available from RPGNow.com in electronic PDF format. To play, all the components have to be printed out with subsequent cutting, folding, and possibly even gluing required."

From the product website:

“Infiltrate a Pacifica research facility with your hired Ronin and their mercenary team. Hack the installation computer net with your Fader. Lay down the firepower with the Gun-suit heavy combat unit. Kick ass. Take names. Then put the game away till you do it again the next day...”

Game is available from http://www.blackpowdergames.com

This game is out of print.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: The Water Cycle
description: This is a game that will help you to better understand The Water Cycle.

name: Corner
description:
An entertaining pastime...An educational sport (from the box cover). The game is very similar to Pit but was made in Australia. However no further information is included either on the box or in the instructions. The appearance of the box and cards suggests a relatively old game.
The cards consist of 6 commodities: Wool (100); Sheep (80); Wine (70); Lead (60); Hides (50); Tin (40) plus a Broker and a Corner King card. There are a few differences between this game and Pit but the general play appears the same.

name: The Tennis Game
description:
(Please note: there is no publication date on this game. The date entered above is an estimate.)

A simple tennis game. It comes with a board, a cardboard "ball" token, a deck of movement cards, and a deck of action cards for each player. Each action card deck contains a result for a serve and a volley (e.g. "Ace on serve, Smash to Crosscourt on Volleys"). Movement cards specify places on the court with the occasional special action, such as "Slipped/Fell". Players start with a hand of cards and must play movement cards facedown before the opponent's action card is revealed. If the player's movement card took them to the appropriate spot on the board to return the shot, then they get to play an action card.

name: World Cup in the Void
description:
An interesting card game developed in Hong Kong. Based on a comic story about the famous soccer players in the world.

There are soccer player cards and another 5 set of action cards with different background color. Each player starts with 11 soccer player cards and 25 action cards.

By playing the action cards, player can tackle, pass or shoot. There are 5 numbers on each of the soccer player cards, to represent their strength in different abilities, like tackling, passing or shooting the ball.

name: Gambler's Paradise
description:
This board game simulates gambling in casinos. Travel between places like Las Vegas and Atlantic City and place your bets.

Includes standard casino games: poker, blackjack, sports betting, and slot machines. Also includes things that some people don't like to admit are gambling: auctions, loan sharks, lottery, and stock market.

Includes basic rules for poker and blackjack, so it could be good for a beginning gambler to practice with before going to a real casino.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Simulation, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Warrior Quest
description:
The game takes place in the sixteenth century in Japan. Japanese warlords fight the power hungry Shogun tyrant for control over the land and its precious commodities. Only you, using your knowledge of the martial arts gained while playing the game, can enter the castle and assassinate the Shogun and end the tyranny.

The game can be played solitaire or with up to 6 players and it comes with a lot of fun bits.

Two different 22” square mounted boards, one representing the village, the other the castle. Lots of cards representing characters, encounters and weapons. Four spinners for fight results depending on board and circumstance, 4 different multi-sided dice, fifty red discs, and most retro of all, pointed sticks to write on six Warrior Character ranking pads and one Shogun score pad, all erasable by lifting the transparency with flick of the wrist.

name: 9 Tibbit Edition
description:
Tibbits is a variation and combination of several games - but played with cubes. The cubes have A, K & Q on them (like cards) and in different colors. You try to build combinations (like 3 identical As, A-K-Q of the same color, etc.) and collect chips based on what colors and combinations you make. There's also a game called "Tic-Tac-Tibbit" included. Nice family game. Any number. Ages 8 and up.

A complete copy should include: Gameboard, 9 Tibbit Cubes with dice cup & lid, 60 chips, Folio, pad, pencil & instructions.

name: Treffles Playing Cards
description:
The Treffles deck is made up of 40 cards, each divided into three segments containing zero to three dots. Five games are described in the rules:


The Snake - a matching game
Treffles Gin - a Gin Rummy adaptation
Sluff - a "Spite and Malice" style matching game
High or Low - a trick-taking game
Partners - a Concentration/Memory game


Re-implemented by: Space Dominoes
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Memory, Set Collection, Team-Based Game, Trick-taking

name: Hit Oder Shit
description:
A dice game in which the player draws the top card and then takes any number of dice with which he attempts to roll the number on the card exactly.

HIT: If he rolls the number exactly, he scores that many the points and it is the next player's turn.

SHIT: If he rolls over the target number, all points the over the target number count as negative and are subtracted from his score, which can become negative. His turn is over.

Not yet decided: If the player does not hit the number on the card, but rolls under the number, the card stays in the game. The following player may then attempt to roll the difference between the first player's roll and the target number, where he also chooses a number of dice from those that remain. He adds his result to the previous one and proceeds as given under HIT or SHIT as appropriate.

If a player's TOTAL roll is over the target number his roll is ignored for progress this round. He loses points. The dice he rolled are returned to the available stock. Each Player has only one attempt per round. If the target number (or the target difference) is exactly achieved by a player then the round ends immediately and the new round begins with the player to the left of the previous starting player. If no more dice are available, or all players have been once, the round ends and the Player closest to the target number (the player with the last valid roll) scores the sum of all valid dice showing.

There are four different special cards.

name: Reaganomics
description: Control money, missiles, go to war, win the Jelly Bean fund, avoid ABSCAM and the unemployment line, go to a CIA fund raiser. Roll-and-advance game, first player to balance the budget wins. Parody game since during the Reagan administration the budget was never balanced and the debt increased each year.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Twisted Tongue
description: Using silly words and a little brain power, try to get your friends to make a mistake in this quick playing, and highly entertaining nonsensical word game. There are multiple levels of play. Try using only the easy words and passing the cards, or use the full rule set for plenty of mind bending fun for the whole family.
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Word Game

name: Legless
description:
The virtual pub-crawl boardgame comes in a convenient, laminated A3 format * including rules of play and scorecards.

The object of the game is to visit all 7 pubs on the board without consuming more than 70 units of alcohol or spending more than £50 ( or the equivalent - pennies, monopoly money or even matchsticks will suffice )

Food outlets and feature squares enable players to reduce their units and add to their dwindling money reserves - there's even a betting shop for those who fancy their chances and a park for chilling out.

Although the luck of the dice is important, a fair bit of skill and judgment comes into the gameplay strategy.

The game takes about 20 - 30 minutes to complete and is readily understandable for ages 8 upwards. In theory any number of people can play but 2-6 players is ideal.


The game can be customized to any town or area - send us details of your seven favorite pubs, take-aways etc. and we will make you a personalized version.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Adventure, Deduction, Dice, Economic, Humor, Maze, Party Game
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: Escort: The Game of Guys and Gals
description:
Object is for the player to move all three of his 'Gals" from their starting places on the board and into their "homes" on the opposite side of the board.

They're escorted home by the nine 'Guys' of each respective player.

Opposing 'Guys' can be captured by jumping.

'Guys' & 'Gals' can move in any direction, backward, forward, left, right or on diagonal.

'Gals' cannot jump and can only be used to block moves.

First player to succeed in getting all three of his 'Gals' into their 'homes' on the opposite side of the board wins the game.
publishers: John Sands Pty Ltd, Parker Brothers, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Master Herbalist
description:
Object of the game is collect as many illness sets determined by the players.

In his/her turn, each player draws and Illness Card. He then places the card face up in front of him. The player then draws an Herb Card. He then has one chance to identify one illness that is listed on the Herb Dial under that Herb.

If the player is correct, he may retain the Herb Card.

It the Herb Card matches the illness of the card or cards he has, the player has the option of placing it under that illness card or saving it for other possible illness sets.

Winner is the player who first completes the predetermined number of Illness Sets.

name: Case Race
description:
Welcome to West's Great American Case Race Game. The objective is to have some old-fashioned fun as you learn the advantages that determine success in computer-assisted legal research. But that's not all. It's a fast-moving game, and it will take some strategy and thinking to win. You will have to make a lot of on-the-spot decisions. The challenge makes the game all the more fun! The rules are straightforward and most of the rules for the game are printed on the board itself.

—description from the publisher

West Publishing Company was the parent company for the Westlaw computer-assisted legal research service, which this game was apparently designed to promote over a competing service, Lexis. The game includes Westlaw and Lexis cards. The Westlaw cards usually score points for the player due to its purported efficient and easy-to-use services, while the Lexis cards typically cause the player to lose points because of purported 'difficulties' with the competitor's legal research service.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Speed Dash
description:
Speed Dash!! The Great Sailplane Race.

Strategic decisions you make in The Great Sailplane Race are much like those in real soaring competition. Whether you stay on the main course or fly Cloud Streets, Ridge Lift, or the Wave depends on the situation, how your competitors are doing, and how gutsy you are. A word of warning: Speed Dash brings out the tiger in a pilot!

name: Reincarnation
description:
Reincarnation. An adult game.

"Discover your past lives -- from centuries to thousands of years ago."

"Although Reincarnation is actually a game, the instructions for play and our approach to it are rather serious."

Roll the Astragali Bones. Consult the Karma Cards. Use the Locater Disc to chart the place of your past lifetime on a map of the world (including the lost continents of Atlantis and Lemuria, of course.) Determine your past life type - nomadic, rural, or city. Determine the time era of the past life, and the livelihood - court astrologer, teacher-philosopher, farm hand, ship's captain, tribal slave, etc. What past lives will the Soul Pattern Cards reveal for you?

name: Word Pyramid
description: A 3D twist on word games. Word Pyramid comes with a large 3D pyramid upon which you stick the letter tiles. Players race against the clock to build words crossword-style onto the game board.

name: Flight Simulator
description:
The APR Flight Simulator is a unique pilot's training device. Developed and tested for several years by leading aviation experts, Flight Simulator answers the need for more realistic ground training by simulating the psychological atmosphere of actual in-flight conditions.

"As each pilot flies his cross-country flight, situations are programmed that test his flying abilities. By reference to components of the Flight Simulator, incorrect responses are immediately observed, analyzed, and explained. Greater insight generally results from group discussion of the particular situation."

"Each pilot selects a flight course according to his proficiency level. When the Flight Simulator is used by more than one pilot, it becomes a competitive cross-country race. The more experienced airmen are handicapped by flying programmed courses demanding greater skills, and the point score is given consistent with the appropriate knowledge. A student pilot can compete with the private or commercial pilot, while all are fully challenged by the situations encountered."

"The Southwestern area of the United States has been chosen as Flight Simulator country in answer to the Simulator's need for the greatest variety of flying terrain. The map-board is WAC scale, 1 inch=1,000,000 inches."
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Squeeze the Juice
description:
The game where lawyers get rich and justice comes at a hefty price.

You have just been selected as one of O.J.'s [Simpson] Defense Attorneys and given an initial retainer of $75,000.00. Your objective is to gain control of as many aspects of the trial as you can, then utilize this control to accumulate more of O.J.'s Defense Fund checks than any other defense attorney.

A variation on Monopoly.

name: U.B. the Judge
description: This game is designed to be as realistic as possible, while still retaining the fun quality of a board game. While it is first and foremost a game to entertain the players, it is educational because the criminal defendants who are convicted are sentenced in a manner typical of the criminal justice systems of the United States. To add more realism, it follows the felony determinate sentencing laws of the State of California. The crimes are taken directly from the California Penal Statutes. The sentencing rules are the sentencing laws of the State of California.

name: The Game of Numismania
description: Players move around the board buying coins at auctions, coin shops and flea markets, trading and selling them. The player with the most money wins the game.. The game can also be played solitaire to see how much money one can make. An interesting twist in the game is that players use actual, current coin prices for their transactions. Thus the players need a current coin price book to play the game.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Mating Game
description:
The Mating Game is a personality profile game which is supposed to compare your personality to that of your mate (or any other person) to see how compatible you are with each other. It uses a set of four cards to determine your personality. Each card has questions from one of four categories; "The Real Me", "For Love and Money" (Tastes and Attitudes), "Do Your Thing" (Interest and Activity Preferences) and "Let's Talk About the Scene" (Controversial Opinions). There are also blank cards included so that players can create their own questions. There are 20 questions on each card, each with three possible answers. For example, the first question under "The Real Me" is "I keep records of my expenditures; a)Yes, b)No, c)Sometimes". There are a, b and c columns on each card. Players use special hole punches to punch out the column corresponding to their answer.

When all players have punched their answers the cards are placed in pairs in the "reader" and the number of common answers are noted by checking to see where the punched holes overlap. The players with the most overlaps are considered to be the most compatible.

name: Taino
description:
From the Davans Website:

Taíno: the Game ™
Moving the Wooden Spheres
Made by Davans for two players 8 years to adult.

Make lines of 3, 4, 5, or 6 spheres to capture unplayed spheres from your opponents reserve pile, but make sure that no line contains more than one sphere of the same color. Once captured, turn the opposing spheres over to make them allies.

The Taíno Legend
Before time memorial, the legendary Taíno peoples who inhabited the Caribbean island of Borikén played an abundance of board games, most of them now time forgotten. Some of these games they played not as a form of entertainment, but rather as a means to more useful ends. "Moving the Wooden Spheres" was one of the games that were played in special occasions, and then only by the cacikes (chiefs) of the tribes. The game was played when it became necessary to settle a dispute between two tribes. It was then that two peaceful minds would engage in a battle of wits—for it was sacrilege for Taínos to wage war amongst themselves; although, they were fearless fighters when their small island had to be defended; as it happened quite often when the bloodthirsty Caribes came charging across the sea from their strongholds in the Orinoco Delta in what is now Venezuela. They raided the island repeatedly looking to slay the Taíno warriors and take their women and children to use as slaves, but the Caribes were always driven back.

To play the game the cacike of each tribe was "armed" with eighteen wooden spheres, three of each of six types of wood. Each cacike would appoint a warrior to "move the spheres" as he/she instructed. (The great cacike Yuisa of the Haimanio Yukayeke was probably the first female ruler in America).

The two "combatants" would set the spheres at opposite edges of the batey (a plaza, used for tribal ceremonies—and as an immense gameboard when there was a need to "move the spheres"). The "movement of the spheres" would begin as the older cacike conceded the honor of moving the first sphere to the younger, less experienced one; thereafter the two appointed warriors would alternate turns moving the spheres as the cacikes instructed into pits (36 in total) dug out of the hard surface of the batey following strict rules of placement.

name: Veptheca
description:
Veptheca is an abstract strategy game for two or more players, which is played with pen and paper.
The board of Veptheca is a arbitrary quad-board with dots. The minimal size is 3x3 points, but bigger is better, for more strategy. Of course, for more than two players, a bigger field must be used.
Every player draws a vector on the field, with the following rules :

1. Orthogonal vector with length 1 (the distance between two neighbor dots in same line or column) with arbitrary direction, if the vector doesn't intersect any existing one.

2. Vector, which is a sum of two existing connected vectors with joint vertex in case :

* is discreet (i.e. lies on two dots from the field);
* doesn't intersect existing vector;
* the joint vertex of the vectors, which sum is, is its vertex too;
* lies in the sub-plane defined by the non-obtuse angle defined by the two vectors, which sum is it;
* is not a result of two collinear vectors;

The winner of the game is the player who makes the last possible move.

The official game site (for rules and examples) is http://veptheca.tuzsuzov.com/

name: Computer Basketball
description:
Brings the thrill of the basketball court to your own easy chair. You and your opponent analyze your own plays -- choose your winning strategy. Game gives you all the results. Baskets scored -- fouls -- out of bounds, etc. The fun, action, and excitement of the basketball court. It's all here.

Electronic Data Controls Corporation released a series of electronic board games under their "Computer Games" line, primarily consisting of two-player sports games. The games all used large wooden game boards depicting the playing field and a game matrix of various results. Each end of the game board had a set of buttons (i.e. offense and defense) that, depending on the combination pressed, would cause a light to illuminate next to one of the rows on the game matrix. The players would then consult the appropriate column to find out what happened.

name: Computer Golf
description:
"No need to reserve a tee off time. Enjoy Computer Golf -- at home. Here's all the fun of an afternoon on the course. Designed for two players, three or a foursome. Computer Golf loses your ball, gets you in and out of the woods, shoots a birdie, etc. All the fun and frustration of the real thing."

Electronic Data Controls Corporation released a series of electronic board games under their "Computer Games" line, primarily consisting of two-player sports games. The games all used large wooden game boards depicting the playing field and a game matrix of various results. Each end of the game board had a set of buttons (i.e. offense and defense) that, depending on the combination pressed, would cause a light to illuminate next to one of the rows on the game matrix. The players would then consult the appropriate column to find out what happened.

name: Computer Sailing
description:
Hold your own regatta. Here's the exciting game of sailing that's designed for up to four players. A lot of fun for the sailing enthusiast or anyone who enjoys competitive sports.

Electronic Data Controls Corporation released a series of electronic board games under their "Computer Games" line, primarily consisting of two-player sports games. The games all used large wooden game boards depicting the playing field and a game matrix of various results. Each end of the game board had a set of buttons (i.e. offense and defense) that, depending on the combination pressed, would cause a light to illuminate next to one of the rows on the game matrix. The players would then consult the appropriate column to find out what happened.

name: Computer Football: Scrimmage
description:
Box blurb: "Fast paced and exciting. An electronic football game that tests your football knowledge."

A smaller format version of the earlier "computer" sports games by Electronic Data Controls Corporation (EDC). Instead of the circuitry and buttons being placed inside an oversized table-filling board, Scrimmage used a small plastic board and console. The players are in control of competing football teams. The simple circuitry inside the game board helps determine the results of each play: yards lost or gained, interceptions, fumbles, etc.

EDC released a series of electronic board games under their "Computer Games" line, primarily consisting of two-player sports games. The series of games released in the late sixties used large wooden game boards depicting the playing field and a game matrix of various results. Each end of the game board had a set of buttons (i.e. offense and defense) that, depending on the combination pressed, would cause a light to illuminate next to one of the rows on the game matrix. The players would then consult the appropriate column to find out what happened. Scrimmage used a much smaller plastic gameboard which wasn't much larger than the size of the matrix.

name: The HexGames
description:
One of the so-called "Penny Games" from tjgames, The HexGames are variations on both Reversi and Checkers, using a hexagonal board with hexagonal spaces, instead of a square board with square spaces. The game is basically a board printed on heavy-stock paper, and a set of rules; you're supposed to supply the pieces for the games.

From the envelope: "Take a checkers board, grab it by the two sides in the middle, and pull really hard until you stretch it into a hexagon. Now you have the basic idea behind the HexBoard Games. A cheap Hollywood remake of two classic 8x8 board games, Checkers and Reversi. If you really did try stretching your checkers board and it ripped ... sorry about that."

Hexversi requires 91 penny-sized pieces that are differently colored on each side. Hexchex requires 12 standard checkers for each player.

name: Academie
description:
This is a rather old Dutch party game. (No publication date is mentioned, but the language used is somewhat archaic).

Players move forward on a board. Every time they land on a space, they have to answer a question or perform a task. If they answer incorrectly, or fail to perform the task, they are moved back to their original space. The first player to reach the target space is the winner.

name: Tight Squeeze
description: Mattel called it the "snuggle-struggle game". Looks to be sort of a dexterity based game similar to Twister - probably their answer to it after they saw how popular Twister was... Target market - teens or maybe adults?

name: Teddy Bears & Tigers
description:
From the box:

All players help the dreaming Little Boy, chased by Tigers, collect all 4 Teddy Bears & Toy Collection. Then, get him back to bed before he wakes up. Take turns moving the Little Boy to Dream Places such as Sea Bottom, a Spooky Castle, a Huge Dragon Mouth, etc. Use Dream Tools such as a Bag of Magic Dust, Large Stilts, and even a very loud Bugle to help him on his way. You might also find Yummy Candy. But too much Candy will give the Little Boy a Tummy Ache and wake him up. However, the biggest dangers are the Tigers, who keep coming closer and closer to the Bed. Work together to help the Little Boy's dreams come true.

A tribute to the comic strip Nemo in Slumberland.

name: Walk a Crooked Mile
description: A very simple game where you have to spin a spinner. If the spinner matches the next space (up or down) then you get to move to the next space and spin again. If it does not match then your turn ends.

name: Mario Andretti's Racing Rage
description: A simplistic racing game in which players roll dice to determine how their car moves. If they stay "on line", they move faster; if they move "off line" they must spend parts cards to continue moving (or move backwards to collect the cards they are missing).

name: Power Quest
description:
Power Quest is an elaborate roll-and-move game with mechanics that will be very familiar to nearly everyone. There are elements here from backgammon, pachisi, Careers, you name it.

The vague back story has players controlling "agents" that move about the board "...in your struggle against the odds to obtain money, prisoners, and position".

The square gameboard is printed with four concentric rings of spaces. Each turn players roll two dice to move one of their three tokens - pardon me, "agents" - out of their headquarters on the outer ring and around the board. Agents can be sent back to HQ by enemy agents, can form blockades, can fall into traps and be captured, and in general are used to make money and harass the other agents.

Most squares are marked with actions that kick off when agents land on them. Many of these earn money for the players, either as a flat payment or by allowing a simple form of gambling involving the bank and the other players. Other actions include: allowing movement up to the next inner track, drawing "Fate" cards that dole out random goodness and badness, starting an auction that sells fallen agents to the highest bidders, and traps that may be inconveniently activated by other players.

The rings get progressively more generous and dangerous as agents move to the inside. Agents captured by an opponent's action (rather than a game mechanic) don't re-enter the game, so the number of agents in play gradually diminishes. The game ends when only one player's agents are left on the board. Players sell (ransom, I suppose) their captured prisoners, and the most money wins the game.

This appears to be a limited run home brew, but it comes in a sturdy box and the production values are good. Both the "Regular Play" and "Advanced Play" rules booklets are well-organized and pretty clear. Advanced rules include solitaire, partnership and a host of other variants.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Striker Out
description: A bingo-like game with a baseball theme. Each player has a card showing the baseball diamond of a particular home team, and there is a stock of chits which depict either player positions or strikeouts for each team. Chits are pulled and the first player to fill all positions on the diamond before getting three strikes is the winner.

name: Mister Ed, The Talking Horse
description: Merchandising of the American television show. Each player has a Mister Ed TV show card and must collect all the corresponding scene cards for that TV show. This is accomplished by rolling dice, moving around the board, and collecting cards at the appropriate spaces. After the cards are collected the player must move his pawn to the stable to win. The scene cards contain such hilarious quotes from the show as "Yes, I'll take good old Addison any day" and "No, don't touch it. It hurts."
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection
publishers: Franz Schmidt, Parker Brothers, Verlag Schmidt Zwiebeltürme

name: Fußball
description: Soccer using pawns...

name: Tacheles
description: This is a game about phrases. One player draws a card and reads out loud the phrase. The other players have to make a statement with this phrase. But they have to do it without the other players seeing it. If the answers match with the answer from the card-reading player, you get points. The one with the most points wins.

name: Piratenschatz
description:
Theme
An old pirate has hidden three treasures on an island. In this 2-player deduction game for children, one player is a treasure hunter trying to find the treasures while the other player gives hints on where the treasures are hidden. Afterwards, the players change roles.

Goal
Earning the most points by correctly locating the treasures while needing as few hints as possible.

Game play
The game board shows an island with 15 connected circles. These are the potential hiding places for the treasures. Each circle is identified through a symbol and also shows one, two or three dots. There are also 15 cardboard discs corresponding to the hiding places (same symbol). The discs have a hole in them.
One player starts the game as the first treasure hunter. He/she gets the 3 red markers and tries to find the three treasures.
The other player shuffles the discs, draws three of them and looks at them, without letting the treasure hunter see them. These discs specify the locations where the treasures are. The other discs form a face-down stack.
The treasure hunter then takes the first disc from the stack and places it on the corresponding location on the board. His/her opponent checks how many treasures are adjacent to that location and marks this by rotating the tile in such a way that the hole shows the same number as dots as there are treasures on adjacent spaces. This is repeated until the treasure hunters thinks he/she knows where the three treasures are. He/she marks the suspected locations with the red markers. Then the actual locations of the treasures are revealed. The treasure hunter gets positive points for location discs not used, and minus points for incorrectly marked locations.

Then the players switch roles.

The game ends after 6 rounds. The player with the most points wins the game.

name: Die Schwindler GmbH
description: This is a bidding game. You have to bid for cards with liars. And you can lie too. First everyone chooses a card with a bidding amount from his hand and puts it face down in front of himself. Then everyone starts bidding. If no one will bid any higher, the bidder with the highest amount shows his card. If the amount on the card is equal or higher, he get the liar card. If not the next player shows his card. There are 12 liars card to bid. The one with the most liars cards wins.

name: The Road to Dien Bien Phu
description: The Road to Dien Bien Phu is a two player military simulation of the First Indochina War; the struggle between the French Union who sought to retain Indochina within its influence and the Vietnamese Communists (the Vietminh) who wished to be independent of French control. The game portrays all of Northern Vietnam and Laos from the end of 1950 to the end of 1954, when the decisive campaigns of the war were fought.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hexagon Grid, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Vision Impossible
description:
A variant of Rummy 500, using a board and a deck of cards with optical illusions on them. Here's the text on the box:

Vision Impossible
The Optical Illusion Game

An amazing collection of dazzling optical illusions has been brought together to create Vision Impossible, the board game guaranteed to put your eyeballs to the test -- dark glasses are not allowed!

Pit your wits against your opponents' and collect sets of classic crazy illusions to score the highest points -- but be warned, don't take too long, you'll find it's a race against each other!

Vision Impossible is an exciting new game, based on an old favourite, suitable for the whole family.

How to play: Players have to collect sets or runs of illusions, to score points. Vision Impossible is a game which combines skill and tactics, along with a sprinkling of good luck and the ability to endure endless eyeball bombardment by mind-bending optical illusions!

Contents: Vision Impossible board, 50 optical illusion playing cards, full instructions.

name: Wildstorm: Set 1
description:
Wildstorm Chromium Set One is the first card set published by the newly created Wildstorm Cards. It hit the stores in 1994. The set comprised of 100 chromium cards, 9 refractor cards and 15 autographed cards. It features artwork from Wildstorms fledgling artists including Jim Lee, Scott Clark, J. Scott Campbell and Brett Booth among others.

The flip side includes details of Wildstorms main heroes and villains, and included a set of 10 stats per character which can be used to play a game. This game is currently available for play on gatling Engine. The adaptation features both the chromium front of the cards and the flip side with the stats with a customized card back based on the Set One logo.

The stats featured on Wildstorm: Set One eventually evolved into the popular Wildstorm Collectible Card Game. Although published by the same company, these two games are not compatible with each other.

Online Play

CCG Workshop (no longer available)

name: Auto Repair: A Game of Expenses
description:
Sub-title "What it takes to keep your car on the road". Published in Olympia, WA. Some bizarre symbol for the Company Logo. Components consist of a one-sided Rules Sheet, Gameboard, 6 various color cars, 6 sets of various color chips to match the cars, 2 DICE, and a pack of M-opoly style Money.
Anyway, a M-opoly style board layout with Dividend spaces and cards of various denominations depicted which, when the player lands on THAT card's place, the player can use the card as payment. 2 of these cards are printed in RED and can be held by a player and when others land on the space indicated on that card, then they pay the card holder. If the player holding the RED card(s) land on THAT place indicated by the RED card, it is placed back into the bottom of the deck. DIVIDEND cards can be sold for the amount indicated on them, either to the BANK or another player. TOKENS-(color chips) are given out when a player lands on START and can be placed on any BLACK numbered space NOT in a corner, but only one allowed at a time. Landing on BLACK numbered spaces results in paying either to the BANK or to the player that has a chip in that space. RED spaces and you collect money either from the BANK if empty or the player of the LAST vehicle in the same space. Land in a space with more than 1 vehicle, except corners, and you pay Double Parking penalties to each player there. Landing on Collision spaces and you only pay THOSE costs and no others. Last player in the game with any money is the winner.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Dei Imperium
description: It is the year 4020 CE, and the Human Empire stretches across most of the known universe. Comprised of a multitude of feuding Noble Houses, the universe is one that knows constant strife, be it on the bloody battlefields of hundreds of worlds, or the predatory elegance of the Imperial Court, or the cutthroat monopolization of trade. This is the world that you will step into to lead your faction to absolute victory!

name: Farb Flitzer
description: Players roll in order of their position on the track. On his turn, a player rolls three color dice and advances on the track by moving through spaces that match the colors rolled. If two of the dice match, the player can jump ahead. A simple game of color matching and sequencing Ages 4 and up.

name: Tri-Zar Levitation Game
description: Players agree upon either gravity or levity. TRI-ZAR's magnetic Power Rings can either levitate above the game board or snap down and stick to it. Players combine their memory and strategic skills with a little bit of luck and magnetic force in this challenging and entertaining game. The first player to have three pieces of his color levitating/ sticking down in a row or forming a triangle wins. Includes a triangular magnetic game board and 6 magnetic Power Rings.

name: Chezzle
description: CHEZZLE is something like "chess played with puzzle pieces". Players move puzzle shaped pieces around a checker style board in an attempt to capture the opponent's pieces. Movement is similar to chess in the sense that each pieces shape / type has it's own unique movement. The captured pieces are used to create a puzzle pattern or CHEZZLE which is selected prior to play.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Children's Game, Deduction, Educational, Party Game, Puzzle
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Pattern Building, Point to Point Movement

name: Ecolandia
description:
Ecolandia is a game about environmental problems. Players go around the board and each case has special effects. The map of Italy slowly covers itself of "Problem" cards; a special spot is used to keep "Problems" for the rest of the world.
To solve each problem, a specific combination of "Resources" is needed: laws, money, petitions, media campaign and so on. When a player has the right set, he can go on a ZAT case and roll the die: the result is compared to the difficulty level of the Problem. If he succeeds, he gets a certain amount of "Green points". Anyway, he looses all the resources.
The flavor of the game is given by the trading possibilities: players can cooperate, exchanging resources for other ones or for a certain amount of "Green points". They can choose to give them for a little amount of points, or to try the die to hope for a larger quantity.
The winner is the one who collects the most Green Points. But if in any moment the map of Italy is totally covered by problems, all the players loose.

name: Battles with Micro-Tanks
description:
Battles with Micro-Tanks Miniature rules

These rules are designed primarily to permit you to recreate WWII engagements, both small and large scale, using micro—scale (1:300) units.

The variety of combat situations which occurred during WWII was almost endless. Battles were fought in deserts and mountains, in good weather and bad, with a wide selection of unit types and equipment, and this era therefore offers the wargamer an opportunity to create practically any type of combat situation he desires.

Those rules will allow the wargamer to simulate both small and large scale actions, which retain a high degree of realism, yet are very playable. They permit the players to easily control the large quantity of units sometimes used when gaming in this scale.

The basic ground scale is 1 inch equals 50 yards, and the basic time scale is 1 turn equals 120 seconds. At this particular ground scale, each unit would represent from 4 to 5 actual units, and you may, of course, play this way. However, it was found that using a 1 for 1 vehicle/unit system works out quite well also. For infantry, one (1) 1/2 inch marker, or 1/2 inch base, with 2 or 3 micro—scale figures mounted on it, represents a 6 to 10 men squad. When an infantry squad is referred to in these rules, this is what is meant.

The equipment lists in the tables describe most of the common pieces of equipment used during WWII. If you wish to use others, it should be a relatively easy procedure to add them, adjusting their values relative to the other equipment.

When playing a micro-armour wargame, it usually works best when a disinterested third party is used to settle all judgment disputes. This will help the game to move quickly, with a minimum of disruption.

Another recommendation which can enhance realism, and can also make the game easier to control, is to maintain some form of unit integrity. There are many references available which can be used to determine the actual composition of the units in question. As a rule of thumb, you can use the following:
3 to 5 units per platoon
3 to 5 platoons per company
3 to 5 companies par battalion. Other specialized types of units may be attached for a given scenario. As a minimum, it is required that you maintain at least company integrity. The farthest any unit can be away from any other unit in the company is 2 inches.

name: Election 2000
description: Produced in a limited run of 1000 copies, bills itself as "A Republican Board Game," and features cartoon renditions of Republican notables on the cover in a favorable light while poking fun at the Clintons, Gore, and the "Liberal" press. The game board and "butterfly ballot" cards serves as a memory jog of events during both the 2000 election campaign and the recount process.

name: Decision 2000
description:
Hand-produced in a run of only 10 copies shortly after the 2000 Presidential Election.

Rules are tongue-in-cheek -- in one variant, the winner gets to be President while the loser is appointed "ambassador to Chad."

Includes actual data on the candidates, events and vote tallies.

name: Stop Dot
description:
Made by Mattel in 1969, this game is a sort of 3-D tic-tac-toe with a twist. It sort of looks like modern 3D art work with its bright colors.

It is played on the outside faces of a 3x3x2 block, so there are 36 positions on which to play (the bottom side is not used). To win you have to make a straight row of five dots in five different colors, without putting any dot next to a dot of the same color. The row of five must be orthognal, not diagonal. Obviously for 5 places it has to cross at least two faces.

3-4 player variant too.

name: Old Woman in the Shoe Game
description: Players drop their colored ball into the chimney of the shoe and it exits one of 4 places where they gather pieces to form a bed (bed, blanket and pillow). The last player to complete his bed pops his ball into it and is the winner.

name: Rings & Cones
description:
Rings & Cones is one of A-O-A's line of "Big Games" - and it is big, with a 22"x22" board (large for an abstract) and plastic cones 3" across.

The game is a twist on N-in-a-row games - players are trying to get 5 (in 2-player or team game) or 4 (with 3-4 players) things in a row, but the things can be either the large cones or the rings (in 4 sizes) that fit over them, so you have a 3-D N-in-a-row. In addition, pieces can be moved once placed.

name: Cone Sanctuary
description:
Cone Sanctuary is one of A-O-A's "Big Games," featuring a 23" x 26" roll-up board and pieces 3" across.

Cone Sanctuary is a move and capture abstract played on a hex grid. On your turn you can introduce a new piece, move 1-2 pieces a total of up to 2 spaces, or move your Sanctuary Shield, which is a clear cone that fits over the other cones (pieces) to protect them. You immobilize and capture the opposing pieces by moving next to them, with the object being to reduce your opponent to two pieces (which prevents capturing).

The game is basically for 2 players, but can be played by 2 teams (it says).

name: Disc-Triangles
description:
Disc-Triangles is one of A-O-A's "Big Games," with a 25" x 25" board (large for an abstract) and pieces 3" across.

The game is a sort of Reversi/Othello variant - as in that game, you try to surround the opposing pieces and flip them over to your color. The difference is in how surrounding works. Here, you can do it either Go-style (occupy all points orthogonally adjacent to a group) or with three pieces that form the points of a right triangle (flipping all pieces inside the triangle). In an additional twist, the outer edge of the board can only be played on when forming a triangle, and otherwise can be used to help surround pieces.

The game is basically for 2 players, but claims it can be played by 4 in teams.

name: Elementare Watson!
description:
Elementare Watson! is a simple trivia game published in several issues in Italian newspaperkiosks. The first issue contained all you need to play and the other ones additional decks of question cards, together with a magazine and a collection of videotapes with Sherlock Holmes TV short movies.
The theme of the questions was mystery and murder, both in books/movies/tv/comics and in reality. A contribute to the questions has been given by the Italian game designer and Murder Party author Antonello Lotronto.
The map depicts London at the end of the 19th Century, A track leads from Scotland Yard to the Docks. Players start at Baker Street and advance when their answers are correct, while they go back if they are wrong. Some cases on the map allow interaction and duels between the players.
The first one to reach the Docks arrests Mr. Moriarty and wins the game.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Murder/Mystery, Trivia

name: Melathlon: Il gioco per mangiare da campioni
description:
This is a promotional game published by CONI (Comitato Olimpico Nazionale Italiano - the Italian Olympic Committee) and UNAPROA (the Union of fruit producers of Italy) to be printed in 50.000 copies and distributed for free in youth sport clubs. The aim was to underline the importance of a balanced diet on sport activity.
Players go around the map collecting several kinds of food. When they go to a sport competition, if they have a complete and balanced diet they have a bonus on their dice roll. Fruit is a joker (you can understand it if you think about who published it!).
Some questions about sports can allow players to get a few gaming aids.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: The Loan Game
description: Players try to be the first to receive a loan by obtaining the equity needed, as called for on individual proposal. Equity is obtained by acquiring cash to make purchases.

name: The Big Guy Game
description:
The Big Guy Game pitches itself as a chance for players to become big stars in the radio entertainment industry. Released during the heyday of WKRP in Cincinnati, a television show about life in a fictional radio station, the board game features prominently a prominent character of WKRP, Arthur "Big Guy" Carlson, in its presentation and theme.

In the game, players roll a die and move their tokens by its result on the board, following instructions printed on the spaces the tokens land on. Players draw a card (from one of five decks) when their tokens land on certain spaces; these cards task the players to read out tongue twisters, news bulletins, and ad lib to scenarios. These performances at being sports announcers, comedians, and talk show hosts could advance the players' positions in the game. The first player to move his token to the last spot (the star) on the board wins and ends the game.

name: Airhead
description: Players stack hats on the body while the head floats higher and higher. Be careful not to let the head fall or the hats fall.

name: Rocket Race
description:
A vintage game titled as "An exciting Space-ship race around the Solar System".
